newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch call rate squeezes up, but relief expected.
newsitem.headline: Dutch call rate squeezes up, but relief expected.

text.p: Dutch call money rates rose further on Monday as the market was somewhat short of liquidity, but an extra inflow of funds was expected on Tuesday which could bring rates a little lower again.

Dealers said the settlement of Dutch Treasury Certificates (DTCs), the short-term borrowing programme of the Dutch government, could be behind the current rise in the cost of overnight money. "Those settlements pull liquidity out of the market," said one dealer.
But another said some 700 million guilders in public health insurance funds were expected to flow into the market tomorrow.
Call money rates rose to 2.87 percent bid in mid-afternoon on Monday, after the rate jumped to 2.75 percent on Friday from a low of 2.38 percent bid on Thursday.
Other rates were stable, and dealers noted most trade in two- and three-month deposits. Three-month deposits were bid at 2.92 percent.
Dealers said they did not expect any changes in official rates till the year-end as the guilder remained stable versus the German mark and recent economic data did not require a rate movement.
The guilder was steady at 112.1425 per 100 marks from 112.145 on Friday.
